												This started off as a pretty solid Free-to-Play game!Pros:-Simple gameplay.-No special tricks with the interface. Point to the one of the two actions that you want to do (move, shoot), confirm, execute.-Simple damage and cover mechanics.Cons:-The more you upgrade, the more you die.-Want any "meaningful" upgrades? So did the enemy, and he brought two friends.I upgraded my second free chap with a machine gun... yep, you guessed it! The enemy upgraded too, and brought more of his friends! By the way, the extra kit that your guys carry it slows them down, but it does not slow down the enemy. The more you upgrade, the more you'll die.It's a shame. 												This is basically a strategy game like Xcom or some other grid-based strategy game so there isn't a lot to talk about Frontline Tactics. It's a nice little game to kill some time if you're bored, but that would be better suited for mobile devices than on PC because there are so many other games that is worth your time over Frontline Tactics. 												For those who dont want to god mode. It is not easy but the game is not hard. You can't run and gun, you can't zerg, you have to 'take your time' with each mission, not like 30 min. I complete a very low threat mission in 5-8 minutes, and walk away with at least 30k, from a mission that has a base pay of 18k-21kThis game is simple and easy to use. point and click for movement, for attacks, and use of Skills like smoke bombs. The combat is like many other tactics games, which is I assume, why you went seraching for a tactics games. You deploy your troops, outmaneuver your opponent, have better positioning and over come the odds.Some of the people reviewing this game seem to be upset about the "paywall". I had almost everything unlocked, with out ever spending a dime. Will I spend some money later? Most likely, I like the camo outfits I can get. But I wont be paying for unit upgrades. You can get upgrades from in-game credit. The enemys will not use anything you dont have. If you dont have access to stealth units, the enemy team will not have one. IF you have access to Snipers, then so will the enemy team even if you dont deploy a sniper. So you have plenty of time to accumalate a lot of money and then deck out a new trooper with a new class,  new guns, armor, and skills. The balance I fill is well done, It is a tactics game, you have to out think the mission.Keep your guys alive, you get money for doing so, Get crossfires, you get money for doing do. outside the base payment for missions, you can really rack up some cash with crossfires. I can get 30k-40k off a mission that was only going to pay out 20k. SKILLS, Skills, Skills, SKILLS Pay attention to skills.It will take about 4-5 missions to get a new peice of gear, or skill.After every 5 mission wins you get an unlock you get to choose from new mssion types, an extra trooper or lots of cash, and even new skills.biggest issue, I got a new computer, and when I reloaded Frontline, I had nothing unlocked. It is a big issue, Steam has cloud save, Frontline should be able to incorperate.Not so big of an issue, It does take time to gather the reasources to deck out a new trooper. Posted: August 13, 2014
												Frontline Tactics is a free-to-play squad level, turn-based tactical game where missions become available on a strategic regional map and missions take place on an isometric map based on one of several static locations (Fishing village, tank battle, etc).The basic aim of the game is to complete missions on the game map with the soldiers you have available and the skills and weapons at their disposal.  As you complete more missions you earn credits which can be spent upgrade your team.  For every 5th mission completed, you get to unlock certain strategic options, such as more mission types (Liberate area, Defend area, Timed survival etc), more locations (maps) plus bonuses such as +credits or +team member slots.Its basically a pay-to-pay game, with anything from squad members, solder proficiencies, soldier skills, equipment, weapons, weapon attachments being able to be purchased with in-game credits.  However you do not have to pay, credits can be earned while just playing through missions, which is what I have done.  Its slower, alot slower but, it just means you will have to play alot more missions to get you squad up to spec.I have mixed feelings about about this game.  On one hand the gameplay is fiendishly addictive but, on the other hand it can be enormously frustrating to play.  Luckily its quite forgiving if you get your squad killed or fail a mission as all soldiers have infinite lives and you can replay missions when you lose.What it does do really well is provide a great representation of squad scale tactical battles which are fun and furious and include: use of cover, crossfire, close and ranged combat, thrown explosives, use of camoflague, decent mission variety, overwatch, soldier perks & skills and a decent range of equipment and weapons.What it doesnt do so well is that it isnt balanced on two levels.  It doesnt provide a fair challenge as in alot of missions you will be outnumbered, the enemy will move first in droves and sometimes they will move twice before you even do so and kill several of your men before they have even had a chance to move.  Secondly the rate at which you can upgrade is quite slow depending on your strategy.  However once you do put in a few hours and have completed around 40 missions you will have earned enough credits to have a decent team with dual proficiencies (rifles, smgs, close-combat, hand-to-hand, sniper or heavy weapons) with some armour, some may have grenades (stun, frags) even if your team will have basic skills (one for each proficiency) and basic weapons (which can be upgraded from late 80s to future-tech).  At this stage the game gets to be very enjoyable as even if your enemy gets the jump on you, you should be able to recover and lead your team to victory in most cases.While I havent purchased any in-game credits I did buy the extra soldier dlcs when on sale, and they were more than worth it as you only start your team with 2 solders.  Overall the game is just about recommendable as it is more enjoyable than frustrating and worth the time of anyone who loved Jagged Alliance 2 or any game of that genre.  ** Just be warned that if you are after 100% achievements there is one were you must buy £80/$100/100euros worth of credits just to unlock.  ^^ **

												After playing this game rather heavily for the last week or so I can safely say it is a solid little game to burn time on. Its especially well suited to those moods when you want to game, but also sit back and chill watching something on tv or even just playing with a pet while also distracting your mind.Some call this game pay to win etc. I call BS. I dropped a meager 2 dollars on the DLC complete pack during a sale and that is more then enough of a leg up for even the least tactical minded player to push through the rough start and get ones groove going.Im going to have to say that this is one of the most enjoyable little turn based tactical strategy games with some RPG character development Ive played since the classic fallout tactics and final fantasy tactics , a couple of my fave of the genre.If your looking to start it Id personally wait for a nice discount sale on the DLC to give you that extra oomph, but its not some magic I win button.Im also talking largely from the single player approach. I dont know exactly how the PVP maps play, but if they use your own soldier team then frankly Id not touch it till my squad feels complete from the solo campaign. By that I mean having a solid 5 man squad all with developed primary and 2ndary specialties, and at least the teir 3 weapon in each.That is about where I started to feel like I was playing my characters rather then as the mere meat puppets they start out as in my eyes.Seriesouly if you have any love for the genre, and a few bucks to drop during a sale on the DLC Id stress you DL the game and give it a few missions to pull you in.I think many will be most surprised when they start seeing just how much each unit can be developed and customized over time to suit given play style approaches.Ive re rolled a few characters including some of the pay for dlc guys, playing with comboes to find what I personally like.For example I first tried making my medic a sniper but found the combo so slowed him down as to make him worthless. I ended up using a small arms/ medic who is fairly quick, hits decently hard at close range to defend himself, and move quickly to get to those who need him. A classic field medic approach.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												I was hesitant to download this game from the recent overwhelming bad reviews. This is my first Turn Based strategy game so I really can't write a comparison to other turn based strategies. Yes this is FTP and anyone who ever plays FTP knows that it doesnt mean you can get all the upgrades for free. The publishers do put time and effort into these games so expecting a FTP to be a full equal playing field game is absurd. However, with the current sale going on ($1.99) for all the DLC which includes all the soldiers and 700,000 credits to start was top priority. So this now becomes a review on a small sized game for $2. The graphics are nothing to go crazy over and the maps are very small. The close quarters feel mixed with an awkward range of fire does take a couple matches to get used to. After you start to hammer down the gameplay "tactics" and start spending some of those credits to give your pistolman a MG, your medic and spec ops guys rifles (or whatever your heart desires on any soldier as each can run with 2 weapons and specialties) then this is when the game comes into its own. This is a very fun game for those of you looking for something different. (I mostly play FPS,  Racing, some Strategy and Third Person shooter/action games). For $2 I absolutely recommend this game. If I had to buy all the different soldiers at $6 a piece this review would never have happened, but if you are reading this on the current weeklong sale that started 1/12, then grab this game. You can download the FTP version (125mb) and test it out if you want, then spend the $2 to start having a lot of fun. So grab your mouse, find some cover and neutrilize those damn terrorists!

												It's meh.When playing it's obvious that the game is heavily influenced by XCOM:Enemy Unknown with the grid-based movement, turn-based combat and the ability to customise your squad before a mission. It falls short of XCOM by a massive margin, but it's still a little fun for a couple of hours until it gets boring.PROS:-Runs great on low-end systems, and has good aesthetics. I maxed out the game with Intel GMA400 graphics and a Celeron 900D CPU and it didn't stutter once.-Well, it's free-Can be challenging at times, which can make it more fun-Influenced by XCOM, which does make the game easier to pick upCONS--High-end systems don't get high-end graphics options. Apart from resolution a high-end rig won't see much more than a craptop.-"F2P" mechanics are abysmal. It's a grind once you're out of the starting missions if you want anything "good" to equip your soldiers with.-Maps are small, and there's only a few of them.-Still needs a LOT more features to have the depth required for players to want to play more-Multiplayer is dead-Game becomes boring once it gets repetitive.Overall, if you want to play it, go ahead. It's free, and I will admit that I enjoyed the game for the first 3-4 hours (especially since it ran on my laptop, which made it all the more appealing to me). I'm not recommending it just for the cons that I've highlighted, but someone looking for a free XCOM set in middle east/afghan conflict to dump a couple of hours into in your spare time, sure, download and give it a bash.

												I really wanted to like this game - I've played Fallout 1-3 and a good deal of New Vegas, Wasteland 1 and am still on Wasteland 2.  The first few missions on F.T. weren't bad, but as I got further into the game, the more annoying it became ...I'll start off by saying I prefer turn-based to R.T., and there's what looks like a solid option on here to do either, so I went with t.b.  You CAN do missions this way - but it will end up taking you upwards of 6 RT hours or more if you're like me and you like to turn over every stone, looting as you go ( I hate missing stuff ! ).Ok, so after the first mission or so, it begins to take a really long time - not so bad ?  Well, also, you can't save during combat.  In fact, you can't save AFTER combat either, unless you manage to get back to a base.  On some games I could understand this ... on a game like F.T. where (turn-based) it takes you 6 hrs or more to finish a mission, it's nigh unforgivable.  Even so, that STILL wouldn't be so bad, except ...Whoever designed the layout of some of these missions was a sadistic @#$!  Don't get me wrong here - fighting's great, you can change up weaponry fairly easily, standard stand, crouch, crawl, walk, run ... but when you look at the map and the checkpoints, then eyeball the overall terrain itself, it'd be nice to think if you decided to go one way to get to, say, Checkpoint X on the map, you wouldn't discover 90% of the way there that some hip-high barrels had been placed strategically along the way to ensure that you COULDN'T get there from here ... The iso view is annoying in that way b/c of the level of obscurity you have to deal with (i.e., is that alleyway running behind that building blocked, or is there a clearcut way to get down it and out the other side?).  Generally, any time you have to wonder about that answer in this game, assume the answer is a big fat NO.  The game delights in having you do an amazing amount of backtracking.  Granted, there are a few things you can crawl under.  But there's no climbing over or rolling barrels out of the way.  If you get to a hip high sandbagged wall, there's no way of removing said sandbags from your path so your vehicle can get through ( I tried dynamite even w/o any luck ).  Perhaps if you play the game in R.T. this wouldn't be nearly the hassle that it is in T.B.  Just my 2 cents.
